text: Chronic Kidney Disease, Diabetes Cardiovascular Disease: make the link Primary Care Education Workshop This module was conceived and developed by PEAK Presented by: 11 Acknowledgement of Country 2 3 Recognition Thanks to the Primary Care Education Advisory Committee for Kidney Health Australia (PEAK) who has developed and reviewed this education. Thanks to our volunteer presenters! This educational program is supported by a sponsorship provided by Boehringer Ingelheim and Eli Lilly Alliance. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 3 4 Housekeeping Primary. careKidney. org. au Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 5 This education has been developed in reference to the Kidney Health Australia Chronic Kidney Disease Management in Primary Care 5th edition handbook. To enhance your learning experience please download the app version chronic kidney disease Go! from your iPhone or Android app store. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 5 6 Why use the chronic kidney disease Management handbook app? Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) management in Primary Care handbook provides best practice recommendations for detecting and managing chronic kidney disease in primary care: Easy to use and interactive. Colour coded chronic kidney disease staging table. Colour coded clinical action plans outlining goals of management, key management tasks and treatments to slow the progression of chronic kidney disease. Medication advice and treatment targets. Management framework for common chronic kidney disease complications. Nephrology referral algorithm. Links to additional resources for you and your patients. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia Learning aim Learning outcomes At the end of this workshop participants will be able to: Apply the Kidney Explain how chronic Kidney disease, Diabetes, Health Check to the and cardiovascular disease interact and influence each other. early detection of Chronic Kidney Outline the three elements of a targeted chronic kidney disease assessment (Kidney Health Check) for at risk Disease (chronic kidney disease) in groups. primary care using optimal management Identify individuals at risk of chronic kidney disease who should be of chronic kidney disease to slow or halt offered a Kidney Health Check. . disease progression. Identify the correct clinical action plan to follow according to an individuals chronic kidney disease stage. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 1100 chronic kidney disease in Australia - Treatable If chronic kidney disease is detected early and managed appropriately, deterioration in Kidney function can be reduced by as much as 50%. 1 New treatments can slow the progression of chronic kidney disease by up to 15 years, or potentially longer if started early. 2 1. Blood Hypertension check failure 2. urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (first morning void Obesity preferably) Smoking/vaping 3. estimated glomerular filtration rate History of acute Kidney Every year for first 3 years injury (acute kidney injury) post acute kidney injury, then every 2 years If results indicate chronic kidney disease, repeat Aged ≥ 60 years Once off, unless developing tests. other indications for assessment Refer to the chronic kidney disease Go! app or of Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care, 5th edition. Kidney Health Australia: Melbourne, 2024 the handbook Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 22 Early detection of chronic kidney disease in First Nations Australians Indication for Recommended Assessment assessment frequency Aged 18 years As needed. Screen for red flags of chronic kidney disease: Family history of chronic kidney disease Clinical history of Diabetes, hypertension, obesity, smoking, established cardiovascular disease, acute kidney injury, Low birth weight or recurrent childhood infections Complete Kidney Health Check if concerned. Aged ≥ 18 years At least annually. Complete a Kidney Health Check. Utilise MBS item 715, if appropriate. a) Yellow clinical action plan b) Orange clinical action plan c) Red clinical action plan Answer 3322 Colour-coded action plan Enter review reminders and into practice software Management strategies as for Yellow action plan, plus Frequency of review Every 3-6 months Clinical assessment Iron studies Calcium and phosphate Parathyroid hormone (6-12 monthly if estimated glomerular filtration rate 45mL/min/1. 73m2) Treatment checklist Assess for common issues presenting in chronic kidney disease. Appropriate referral to a nephrologist when indicated. Refer to action plans on pages Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. 26-27 of the handbook Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 33 The presence of albuminuria is an important prognostic feature of chronic kidney disease, and the driver of cardiovascular disease. a) True b) False c) Dont know Question Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 3344 The presence of albuminuria is an important prognostic feature of chronic kidney disease, and the driver of cardiovascular disease. a) True b) False c) Dont know Answer Because Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 3355 Urine albumin/Creatinine ratio (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio) Protein in the Urine is a key marker of Kidney damage and linked to increased risk of progression to Kidney failure and cardiovascular disease. Reduction in urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is reno-protective. Importantly Elevated urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is a more common sign of chronic kidney disease than a decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate and is often missed as part of a Kidney Health Check in practice. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 3366 How to detect albuminuria An initial urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio test should be repeated on a first void sample if the results are positive for albuminuria as urinary Protein excretion follows a circadian pattern. Where first morning void not possible, random spot specimen for urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is acceptable. Dipsticks for Protein in the Urine are now no longer recommended due to poor sensitivity and specificity. urine protein-to-creatinine ratio tests may miss microalbuminuria, resulting in false-negative results. 24-hour Urine collection is not warranted to quantify proteinuria. urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio criteria for chronic kidney disease is not applicable in pregnancy. Dont let perfection get in the way of testing! Random sampling is better than NOT AT ALL Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 3377 Repeating the Urine albumin-creatinine ratio Factors other than chronic kidney disease known to increase Urine albumin excretion: Urinary tract infection High dietary Protein intake Congestive Heart failure Acute febrile illness Heavy exercise within 24 hours Menstruation Genital discharge or infection Drugs e. g. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 38 Diagnosing chronic kidney disease There are three components to a diagnosis of chronic kidney disease Urine albumin-creatinine ratio Underlying chronic kidney disease estimated glomerular filtration rate results results aetiology to give chronic kidney disease Stage (1normo (A1), micro (A2) to determine cause of Diagnosis 5) or macro (A3) chronic kidney disease albuminuria estimated glomerular filtration rate gives the chronic kidney disease stage. Consistent over 3 months Albuminuria is present if two of three tests over 3 months are ≥ 3.

Consistent over 3 months Albuminuria is present if two of three tests over 3 months are ≥ 3. 0 magnesium/mmol Underlying aetiology determines the cause of chronic kidney disease Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 4411 Alcohol lifestyle modification Australian guidelines recommend healthy men and women should Drink no more than 10 standard drinks a week and no more than 4 standard drinks on any one day to reduce the risk of harm from alcohol-related disease or injury. There are no specific recommendations about safe levels of alcohol consumption people with chronic kidney disease, however the less you Drink, the lower your risk of harm from alcohol. Accessed March 15, 2024. www. cvdcheck. org. au Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 53 chronic kidney disease and hypertension A bidirectional relationship Hypertension is both a cause of chronic kidney disease and a complication of chronic kidney disease and can be difficult to control. The risks of uncontrolled hypertension include progression of Kidney disease and increased risk of coronary Heart disease and stroke. Kidney Disease Hypertension Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia Dennis has hypertension. What Blood Hypertension target should he aim for? a) 120/80 b) 130/80 c) 140/90 d) 110/60 Question Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 5555 Dennis has hypertension. What Blood Hypertension target should he aim for? a) 120/80 b) 130/80 c) 140/90 d) 110/60 Question However, when might this target not be appropriate? Discuss as a group. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 5566 Hypertension treatment targets Some evidence and clinical guidelines suggest aiming for a lower blood pressure target (systolic blood pressure 120mmHg) in people with chronic kidney disease who with High cardiovascular disease risk may improve outcomes. Lower blood pressure targets need to be balanced with an increased risk of side effects including increased risk of falls due to hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities and episodes of acute kidney injury. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 6600 Case study - Dennis Dennis GP prescribes an ACE inhibitor and metformin (titrated up to 1g bd). He sees you, the practice nurse, to discuss dietary changes and an exercise plan. Dennis returns for his follow up results. Investigations 1st visit 1 month later Fasting bloods BGL 9. 0 millimoles per liter 7. 0 millimoles per liter 8. 0% hemoglobin hemoglobin A1c potassium 4. 2 millimoles per liter 4. 2 millimoles per liter You notice, Dennis Creatinine 165 µmol/L 183 µmol/L estimated glomerular filtration rate has dropped estimated glomerular filtration rate 40 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 35 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 by 13% Total cholesterol 6. 7 millimoles per liter HDL cholesterol 1. 4 millimoles per liter LDL cholesterol 3. 2 millimoles per liter Triglycerides 2. 4 millimoles per liter Urine albumin-creatinine ratio (early morning) 22. 6 magnesium/mmol Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 61 SGLT2 inhibitors treatment for chronic kidney disease When can SGLT2 inhibitors be used in chronic kidney disease? PBS Criteria: Diagnosis of proteinuric chronic kidney disease (with or without Diabetes) present for ≥ 3 months prior to prescribing. estimated glomerular filtration rate 25 - 75 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio 22. 6 - 565 magnesium/mmol Must be stabilised, for at least 4 weeks, on either: (i) an ACE inhibitor or (ii) an angiotensin II receptor antagonist. Do not use in combination with another SGLT2 inhibitor. Not recommended to initiate if estimated glomerular filtration rate 25 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2. May be prescribed by nurse practitioners (continuing therapy only) Check pbs. gov. au for full prescribing criteria Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) Home Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 62 SGLT2 inhibitors Clinical tip SGLT2 inhibitors cause a reversible drop in estimated glomerular filtration rate 4 weeks after initiation, then rebounds. Specific testing of estimated glomerular filtration rate for this purpose is not required. SGLT2 inhibitors cause osmotic diuresis, reduce diuretics and/or antihypertensive medications upon initiation of an SGLT2 inhibitor. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024.

Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 6633 After starting an SGLT2 inhibitor, Dennis estimated glomerular filtration rate decreases to 32 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 (Creatinine 200µmol/L) Should the medicine be stopped? a) Yes b) No Question c) Maybe Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 6644 After starting an SGLT2 inhibitor, Dennis estimated glomerular filtration rate decreases to 32 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 (Creatinine 200µmol/L) Should the medicine be stopped? a) Yes b) No Answer c) Maybe Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 6655 Diabetic Kidney disease and chronic kidney disease therapy Non-steroidal mineralocorticoid antagonist (nsMRA), finerenone, is PBS listed for diabetic Kidney disease (diabetic kidney disease) to delay progressive decline of Kidney function and reduce risk of CV event in addition to standard care. Tips for using nsMRA PBS approved for use in diabetic Kidney disease estimated glomerular filtration rate 25 - 75 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio 22. 6 - 565 magnesium/mmol Add on therapy to both renal artery stenosis (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker) and SGLT2 inhibitor Predictable drop in estimated glomerular filtration rate and rise in serum Potassium - monitor carefully Do not use in combination with steroidal MRAs (e. g. spironolactone) Bakris GL et al. Effect of finerenone on chronic Kidney disease outcomes in type 2 Diabetes. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 6699 REDUCE: medications excreted by the kidneys Medications that may need to be started at a reduced dose or ceased in patients with chronic kidney disease include but not limited to: Anti-infective Cardiovascular Diabetes Pain Other famciclovir apixaban acarbose gabapentin allopurinol nirmatrelvir dabigatran all gliptins opioid benzodiazepines valaciclovir digoxin except analgesics colchicine antibiotics e. g. rivaroxaban linogliptin pregabalin baclofen ciprofloxacin, sotalol insulin duloxetine trimethoprim, spironolactone metformin escitalopram sulfamethoxazole, sulfonylureas solifenacin aminoglycosides, fenofibrate nitrofurantoin denosumab lithium Metformin reduce dose if estimated glomerular filtration rate 30-60mL/min/1. 73m2 and under specialist supervision if estimated glomerular filtration rate30mL/min/1. 73m2 While dose of reduction of denosumab is not required in chronic kidney disease, the risk of hypocalcaemia increases with more advanced chronic kidney disease Refer to pages 34-35 in Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Avoid NSAIDS and other nephrotoxic medications Early identification of people with acute illness (e. g. GI upset or dehydration) Temporarily cease ACE inhibitors, ARBs, diuretics with hypovolaemia / hypotension Sick Day Action Plan template available in the Kidney Health Professional Hub. Join today! Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 75 Considerations in older people Over 40% of people aged 75 years and over are affected by chronic kidney disease. Individual approach required to address comorbidities, variability in functional status, life expectancy and health priorities. Relying on Creatinine alone causes under-recognition of chronic kidney disease. estimated glomerular filtration rate adjusted for age improves diagnostic accuracy. Treatment choice has more effect on lifestyle than it does on mortality or morbidity. Dialysis therapy may not offer survival advantage compared with non-Dialysis comprehensive conservative care in elderly people with two or more comorbidities.
